DOC.HEAD: Socialist Deputy Escapes Injury In Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A socialist deputy and publisher escaped injury today when his car was blown up outside his home, police said. An explosion caused by dynamite destroyed Makis Kouris' car only minutes after he parked it outside his suburban home but no one was injured, police said. No one claimed responsibility for the blast. A police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said police did not suspect Greece's three well-known urban guerrilla organizations of involvement in the attack. He did not elaborate. Kouris, 47, and his brother, George, own three daily newspapers and a radio station. He was elected to Parliament in June and November. The Kouris' publications are unequivocal in their support for former socialist Premier Andreas Papandreou. But critics in and out of his party have charged them with using muckraking tactics to villify political rivals. The brothers were strongly opposed to Papandreou's party joining with the conservative and Communist parties in a coalition after no party won a majority in November. Following the June elections, Parliament indicted Papandreou and other socialist officials on charges of corruption during their eight years in office. No date has been set for their trials.
